en.text:
Alrightâ€¦ I just found out this girl DOESNâ€™T EXIST ğŸ˜³
Sheâ€™s 100% AI-generated.

And she has more followers than me.

Itâ€™s getting harder and harder to tell whether a photo is real or not. Be careful about idealizing everything you see on social media, because there might not even be a real person behind it.

Recommendation algorithms analyze much more than just your likes.

They measure how long you look at something, whether you pause a video, scroll back, zoom in on an imageâ€¦ even what you ignore.

With all of that, they build a predictive profile of your interests.

They donâ€™t show you whatâ€™s most true.
They show you whatâ€™s most likely to keep you there.

And that completely changes how we consume information.

Many people think that when an AI gives an incorrect answer, itâ€™s because itâ€™s â€œlying.â€ But thatâ€™s not really how it works.

Language models donâ€™t search for the truth â€” they search for the most probable next word based on the data they were trained on. If they donâ€™t have enough information or the topic is very specific, they can generate details that sound completely convincing.

This is called a â€œhallucination.â€
Itâ€™s not malice. Itâ€™s statistics.

So using AI is fine â€” but trusting it blindly isnâ€™t.

A bot isnâ€™t always obvious. Itâ€™s not just an account with a weird username and zero photos.

It can be designed to look completely human: posting memes, commenting on news, interacting with other users.

If hundreds of bots support the same idea, it can create the illusion of real consensus.

And when we believe that â€œeveryone thinks this way,â€ weâ€™re much less likely to question it.

Thatâ€™s where the real problem begins.
